questions.question: Why do complex abilities like learning and consciousness come from many brain cells and circuits, not from one neuron?

options.A: Because each brain part works alone, so adding outputs of single neurons explains higher functions.
options.B: Because cells and circuits interact in complex, nonlinear ways with feedback and network connections that make new patterns.
options.C: Because information is stored only in synaptic chemicals, with no role for network dynamics or interactions.
options.D: Because these complex properties are fixed during development and do not need ongoing circuit activity.

questions.simplification_notes: Used shorter sentences and simple words. Replaced technical phrasing with plain terms like 'cells' and 'circuits'. Kept the idea that interactions, feedback, and network structure create new patterns.
concepts_tested: Emergence: How complex properties of brains and behavior arise from interactions among neurons, glia, and neural circuits.
Multiscale/integrative approach: Connecting molecular, cellular, system, and cognitive levels using diverse disciplines and techniques.
Brain–behavior relationships: The links between neural mechanisms and learning, memory, perception, behavior, and consciousness.

questions.question: In systems theory, 'emergent' means new whole-system traits come from parts working together and can't be explained by any single part. Which explanation best shows how these traits appear?

options.A: Each part has hidden properties that only show up when the parts are joined.
options.B: Parts interact, causing feedback and cooperation that make new patterns you can't predict from any single part alone.
options.C: Emergent traits happen because the system's boundaries stop parts from sharing information.
options.D: Emergent traits are just the simple average of all the parts' properties.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simple words. Replaced technical phrasing like 'nonlinear feedback and cooperative dynamics' with 'feedback and cooperation' while keeping the original meaning and correct answer.
concepts_tested: Emergence and synergy: systems exhibit properties that arise from interactions of parts and are not reducible to individual components.
Boundaries, context, structure, function, and relations: how a system is defined and how its environment and internal organization shape behavior and interactions with other systems.
Adaptation and equifinality: systems learn and adapt depending on engagement with their environment, and different paths can lead to the same end state.

questions.question: Parts of a system follow local rules where small changes can cause big effects. Why does the whole system show new behaviors you can't predict by looking at single parts?

options.A: Because the whole behavior is just the sum of each part's actions.
options.B: Because nonlinear interactions make feedback and links across scales, creating new patterns not found in any single part.
options.C: Because averaging all parts makes the system into one simple trend.
options.D: Because adding more parts always makes the system act in a simple, linear way.

questions.simplification_notes: Removed heavy jargon, split into short sentences, explained 'nonlinear' as small changes causing big effects, kept idea of feedback and cross-scale links.
concepts_tested: Emergence from interacting components: how non-linear, collective dynamics lead to higher-order behaviors not reducible to individual parts.
Organized vs. disorganized complexity: different methodological approaches (probability/statistical mechanics vs. holistic, multi-factor analysis) applied to different types of complex phenomena.
Relational regimes and state spaces as sources of complexity: complexity arises from the number and variety of distinguishable relationships and their possible states within a system.

questions.question: In an experiment, people are randomly put into a treatment group or a control group. Why does random assignment make it easier to say the treatment caused the result, compared to a study where people choose their group?

options.A: Random assignment makes the groups exactly the same and guarantees they will have the same outcomes.
options.B: Random assignment helps balance other factors (both known and unknown) on average between groups. So outcome differences are more likely caused by the treatment.
options.C: Random assignment removes the need for any statistical analysis because any differences are automatically caused by the treatment.
options.D: Random assignment makes the sample perfectly represent the whole population, so the results apply to every population.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simple words. Replaced 'confounders' with 'other factors (both known and unknown)'. Kept the core idea about balancing factors and causal inference.
concepts_tested: Descriptive vs. inferential statistics and how sampling variation affects generalization from a sample to a population
Hypothesis testing framework, including null hypothesis, alternative hypothesis, and Type I/Type II errors
Experimental vs. observational study designs and the role of manipulation/randomization in establishing causal inferences and the importance of representative sampling

questions.question: Why are knowledge networks and collaborations important for how science is done? Think about sharing expertise, special equipment, and tacit know-how (skills learned by doing).

options.A: They make sure everyone has equal access to resources and remove all coordination costs.
options.B: They let the most talented person decide results, no matter how the network looks.
options.C: They shape which problems get studied and how fast ideas spread. Diverse skills and shared equipment help combine ideas, and trust and incentives affect teamwork.
options.D: They always produce fast breakthroughs because international links remove local limits and add no extra costs.

questions.simplification_notes: Used shorter sentences and simple words. Explained 'tacit know-how' as skills learned by doing. Removed technical jargon while keeping the core idea about networks shaping problem choice, spread of ideas, and the role of trust and coordination.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Resource allocation and funding as mechanisms to align science with public interest and economic development.
Concept 2: Knowledge networks and collaborations as essential structures shaping how science is produced (distribution of expertise, equipment, and know-how).
Concept 3: The multi-actor, international ecosystem (governments, firms, NGOs, universities) and its influence on science policy and global research agendas.

questions.question: Why do groups often use both written rules and unwritten habits to guide choices and proper behavior?

options.A: Written rules always give the best result for everyone, so unwritten habits are not needed and can cause problems.
options.B: Unwritten habits can take the place of written rules completely, so the written rules become useless.
options.C: Written rules set clear limits and steps to follow. Unwritten habits help people accept the rules, follow them willingly, and work together when rules are unclear or not strongly enforced.
options.D: Only one type is needed; the group just picks written rules or unwritten habits based only on how big the group is.

questions.simplification_notes: Replaced technical wording with 'written rules' and 'unwritten habits'. Broke complex sentences into short, simple ones and kept the idea that rules give structure while norms give legitimacy and help when rules fail.
concepts_tested: The governance framework as a system of rules, laws, norms, and power dynamics that guide decision-making and acceptable conduct.
The role and structure of governing bodies (formal and informal) in enforcing rules and overseeing group operations.
Governance as the allocation and mobilization of resources and the setting of a collective direction to address needs and challenges.

questions.question: Universalists say the same basic political rights should apply to all cultures. What reason do they give for this, and why do cultural relativists disagree?

options.A: They base rights on a shared human power of reason that applies to everyone. Cultural relativists say moral rules must come from local customs, so universal rules lack authority.
options.B: They copy rights from the laws of the most powerful culture to keep order. Cultural relativists say this ignores and harms minority groups.
options.C: They argue rights depend on history and local context, so no single set fits all. Cultural relativists agree and reject universal norms.
options.D: They point to similar practices across many cultures as proof of universal rights. Cultural relativists reply that practices vary and mean different things.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in short, simple sentences. Replaced jargon with plain words (e.g., 'shared human power of reason' for 'universalizable rational capacity'). Kept the original core idea and correct answer.
concepts_tested: Normative vs empirical study in political inquiry: why political philosophy emphasizes what ought to be (values like justice, equality, liberty) and how this contrasts with empirical political science.

Ideological foundations and justification of political action: how different ideologies (anarchism, liberalism, conservatism, socialism) tie their core values to views on state power, legitimacy, and social order.

Methodological approaches to political knowledge: foundationalist vs particularist methods; universalist vs cultural relativist claims, and how these frameworks shape the construction and critique of political theories.

questions.question: How do action theory and conflict theories explain why social classes stay the same in a modern society? What does each theory say keeps or challenges that order?

options.A: Action theory says classes stay the same because schools, laws, and groups force people into set roles. The mechanism is external force that keeps people in place. Conflict theory says classes stay because people accept roles to keep order.
options.B: Action theory says classes stay the same because people learn roles, meanings, and rules through daily life. The mechanism is socialization and shared meanings. Conflict theory says classes stay because some groups control resources and power. The mechanism is structural advantage and ongoing class conflict.
options.C: Action theory says classes stay the same because of genetic differences. The mechanism is biology. Conflict theory says classes disappear if everyone gets the same education. The mechanism is expanded opportunity.
options.D: Action theory says persistence of classes is random and due to luck. The mechanism is chance. Conflict theory says classes change because of new technology. The mechanism is innovation and economic shifts.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote using short sentences and simple words. Kept the core contrast: action theory = socialization/shared meanings; conflict theory = control of resources, structural advantage, class conflict.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Stratification as a hierarchical system driven by inequalities of status and access to resources, and its correlation with societal complexity.

Concept 2: Bases of stratification (wealth, income, race, education, ethnicity, gender, occupation, social status, power, kinship/caste) that determine individuals’ positions and privileges within the hierarchy.
Concept 3: Theoretical perspectives on stratification (action theory vs. conflict theories/Marxism) and their explanations for social order, mobility, and resource distribution.

questions.question: If people save more, how does this affect business investment and long-run economic growth? Which chain of events explains the link?

options.A: More saving gives people money to spend now, so demand rises and firms invest to meet higher sales.
options.B: More saving raises the amount of money available for loans. That lowers real interest rates and makes borrowing cheaper. Firms borrow to buy machines and buildings. Over time this raises the economy's productive capacity and growth.
options.C: More saving reduces current spending. Production falls and firms cut investment, causing a slowdown.
options.D: Saving and investment happen in different markets, so saving has no effect on investment.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in short, simple sentences. Replaced technical phrases with everyday words (e.g., 'money available for loans'). Split the mechanism into clear steps: saving → more loanable money → lower interest rates → cheaper borrowing → more investment → long-run growth.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Micro vs. Macro analysis as different levels of economic interactions (agents/markets vs. systemic production/distribution/consumption and related variables).

Concept 2: Interactions among production, distribution, consumption, savings, and investment, and how factors of production (labor, capital, land, enterprise) and macro factors (inflation, growth, public policy) shape economic outcomes.

Concept 3: The distinction between positive (what is) and normative (what ought to be) economics and the existence of different theoretical frameworks (rational vs. behavioral, mainstream vs. heterodox).

questions.question: In a cybernetic system, outputs come back as inputs and affect what happens next. How does negative feedback help keep the system steady?

options.A: By ignoring the feedback and keeping the input fixed, so outputs never change.
options.B: By checking the output against a set goal and changing its actions to make the error smaller.
options.C: By always making changes bigger when the output changes, causing fast and unstable shifts.
options.D: By cutting the links between outputs and inputs so no feedback can happen.

questions.simplification_notes: Used shorter sentences and simpler words. Replaced 'reference' with 'set goal' and 'dampening deviations' with 'make the error smaller.' Kept the original correct answer and core idea about negative feedback.
concepts_tested: Circular causality and feedback loops as a mechanism by which a system’s outputs influence future inputs to maintain or adjust behavior.
Recursion and self-organization as processes that generate complex, adaptive behavior from simpler rules and information processing.
The role of information, control, and communication as fundamental cross-domain functions linking systems in biology, machines, and society.

questions.question: Hot rock in the mantle moves and drives plate tectonics. Why does Earth’s surface break into separate plates and plate boundaries instead of acting like one single connected shell?

options.A: Because the mantle has the same strength everywhere, so it drags the whole surface at the same speed and makes it move like one piece.
options.B: Because the lithosphere is a strong, almost rigid shell that sits on a weaker asthenosphere. Mantle forces concentrate at plate edges, letting plates move differently and forming boundaries by slab pull and ridge push.
options.C: Because erosion and moving sediments at the surface push and pull the crust and organize it into plates.
options.D: Because mantle flow cannot make sideways shear in the lithosphere, so the surface would only move up and down.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences, used simple words, split complex ideas into short sentences, kept core idea that a strong lithosphere over a weak layer makes separate plates and boundaries.
concepts_tested: Mantle convection as the driver of plate tectonics and related geologic phenomena
Rock deformation modes (elastic, plastic, brittle) and how stress magnitude and relaxation times dictate deformation behavior
Internal stress–gravity–density relationships and hydrostatic equilibrium, including the role of the equation of state to model density with depth

questions.question: Why do private property and market prices help send resources to their best uses? Why not public ownership or fixed prices?

options.A: Private property gives people reasons to care for and improve things. Prices show scarcity and help many people coordinate choices without a central planner.
options.B: Private property makes income equal, removes competition, and stabilizes production.
options.C: Prices can hide information. Private property can stop learning what people want and so misallocate resources.
options.D: Public ownership solves all coordination problems, so prices are not needed.

questions.simplification_notes: Made the question and answers shorter and simpler. Split the question into two short sentences. Replaced complex words with plain language and kept the main idea that property and prices coordinate many people without a central planner.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Property rights and price formation as organizing forces (private vs. public ownership; the idea of a just price) and their effects on economic activity.
Concept 2: State intervention versus laissez-faire as policy mechanisms and their moral/economic justification.
Concept 3: Division of labor and specialization as a mechanism for production and economic growth (early conceptual discussions of how labor division affects wealth).

questions.question: How does learning from more than one subject help students think more flexibly and solve real-world problems?

options.A: By having students memorize key definitions from each subject to build wide knowledge.
options.B: By keeping each subject separate so students do not mix different methods.
options.C: By showing students different ways and methods from many subjects so they can see problems in new ways and use strategies in new situations.
options.D: By having students focus only on one subject first to get deep expertise before mixing subjects.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in simple language for ages 11–14. Broke ideas into short sentences. Replaced terms like 'explanatory frameworks' and 'transfer' with simpler phrases.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Integration of multiple disciplines to address complex, real-world problems
Concept 2: Interdisciplinary education as a method to foster cognitive flexibility, active learning, and problem-solving through blending approaches from several fields
Concept 3: Emergence of cross-boundary fields or organizational units to meet new needs and incorporate diverse perspectives (including addressing neglected or emerging areas)

questions.question: Why does a system show new properties that no single part has?

options.A: Because the system is just the sum of each part's properties.
options.B: Because parts interact and make feedback loops that change how the system works and create new patterns.
options.C: Because new properties only appear from how we measure things, and they disappear if we look closer.
options.D: Because the study ignored important outside inputs that made the system behave differently.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Replaced technical phrase 'nonlinear feedback and coupling' with 'feedback loops and parts interacting'. Kept the core idea that interactions produce new system-level patterns.
concepts_tested: Emergence and synergy: systems are "more than the sum of their parts" due to interactions that produce new properties.
Interdependence, boundaries, and context: systems have causal boundaries and are shaped by context, with structure, function, and relations determining behavior.
Adaptation, learning, and equifinality: system growth and adaptation depend on engagement with the environment, allowing multiple paths to similar outcomes.

questions.question: Why can what people call "beauty" change from one generation to the next, even if biology does not change?

options.A: People measure beauty and think it becomes an objective fact over time.
options.B: Ideas about beauty form and change through social interaction and shared agreement. People both accept and reshape these ideas.
options.C: Parents alone teach what is beautiful, so standards stay the same across generations.
options.D: Ancient authorities fixed the idea of beauty long ago, and it never changes.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Kept the main idea that social interaction and shared agreement create and change beauty standards. Made all options plausible as distractors.
concepts_tested: Social constructs are formed and sustained through ongoing social interactions and collective consensus rather than direct empirical observation of reality.
The meanings of phenomena depend on mental and linguistic representations, making reality a shared construct rather than an independently given truth.
Individuals actively shape and reinterpret social narratives in a two-way process, wherein internalization and social engagement both influence and modify constructs.

questions.question: In critical theory, how does praxis (mixing ideas and action) help bring about social change?

options.A: By keeping ideas and actions apart and only talking about power in theory.
options.B: By joining ideas with group action so theory guides action and action changes theory, producing real change.
options.C: By choosing neat, complicated theories instead of working with social movements.
options.D: By believing that knowledge alone, without organized action, will make society change.

questions.simplification_notes: Language simplified for middle school. 'Praxis' was explained as 'mixing ideas and action'. Sentences shortened and made concrete. Core meaning and correct answer kept.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Power-knowledge relationship and critique of objectivity
Concept 2: Praxis—the integration of theory and collective action for social transformation
Concept 3: Intersections of oppression within historical/capitalist contexts

questions.question: In the transactional model, people send and receive messages at the same time. They keep encoding and decoding and change what they say using feedback. How does this simultaneity change encoding, decoding, and feedback compared to the linear model where one sender sends with little or no feedback?

options.A: Feedback becomes continuous and two-way. People encode and decode together in a shared frame. They co-create meaning instead of just sending it one way.
options.B: Feedback is not needed because both people send messages at the same time.
options.C: It forces a strict order: one person sends first and the other responds later, just like the linear model.
options.D: It makes communication error-free. Simultaneous exchange cancels noise and guarantees no errors.

questions.simplification_notes: Short sentences, simpler words, removed technical terms, kept the core comparison between transactional and linear models and preserved correct answer A.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Communication models (linear, interactional, transactional) and their mechanisms (encoding/decoding, feedback, noise) and how they differ in directionality and simultaneity.
Concept 2: Transmission vs. ritual perspectives as two foundational relationships framing communication (information exchange vs. social connection) and their implications for interpreting messages.
Concept 3: The role of social context and norms in shaping language use and communication practices (e.g., sociolinguistic findings on formality and context).

questions.question: Peirce's model has three parts: sign, object, and interpretant. Saussure's model has two parts: signifier and signified. Why does Peirce's model explain how meaning forms and changes for different people and situations better than Saussure's? What does this tell us about interpreting signs in different contexts?

options.A: Peirce's interpretant is the mental effect a sign makes on each person. This lets meaning form in ongoing steps and change with context. Saussure's dyad treats meaning as a fixed link between a sign form and a shared social concept. It ignores active, context-sensitive interpretation.
options.B: Saussure's two-part model ties signs to flexible concepts, so it already acts like it has an interpretant. Thus the triadic model seems redundant.
options.C: The triadic model sets a fixed relation among sign, referent, and audience. That would mean the same interpretation everywhere.
options.D: The dyadic model suits non-linguistic signs, while the triadic model is for linguistic signs and contexts.

questions.simplification_notes: Shorter sentences, simpler words, clearer contrast between Peirce's triad and Saussure's dyad. Kept same correct answer and core idea about context and interpretation.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Sign relation frameworks (Saussure's dyadic model vs. Peirce's triadic model) and how they explain meaning
Concept 2: Relationship between signs, meanings, users, and context (semantics, pragmatics, texts, codes)
Concept 3: Classification of signs into iconic, indexical, and symbolic, and implications for interpretation

questions.question: How does structuration theory explain the link between social structures and people's actions? Why can't one alone decide what happens in society?

options.A: Structures fully determine actions; people only copy structures and do not change them.
options.B: People act independently of structures and create social order that structures cannot limit.
options.C: Structures both help and limit actions, and daily practices can reproduce or change structures in a continuous feedback loop.
options.D: The theory says big structures always decide small actions, so micro differences do not matter.

questions.simplification_notes: Split into two short sentences. Used simple words and short sentences. Kept the idea that structures enable and constrain actions, and that everyday practices reproduce or change structures in a feedback loop. Correct answer unchanged.
concepts_tested: Duality of structure and agency: structures shape actions and actions reproduce/transform structures; neither dominates, and neither micro nor macro analysis alone suffices.
Social practices across space and time: social life is constituted by practices ordered through time and space, forming the basic domain of study and enabling the reproduction of social systems.

Interdisciplinary/ontological approach: the theory integrates phenomenology, hermeneutics, and insights from geography, history, philosophy to address the abstract characteristics of social relations beyond purely empirical methods.

questions.question: Social control means the rules and punishments that keep a society in order. The "paradox of deviance" says breaking rules can sometimes make that order stronger. How can breaking rules do this?

options.A: It makes shared beliefs weaker and slowly breaks common rules.
options.B: It shows rules are random and always open to change, so people obey less.
options.C: It shows the line between right and wrong, so most people reaffirm their shared values.
options.D: It pushes rule-breakers out and makes new groups that replace the main society.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences, used simple words and active voice, explained 'paradox of deviance' plainly, kept the original meaning and correct answer.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Informal vs formal social control as mechanisms by which behavior is regulated to maintain social norms and order.
Concept 2: The paradox of deviance in social control (deviance as both regulated by and defining social norms, reinforcing conformity).
Concept 3: The role of institutions (government, religion, civil society) in formal social control to prevent chaos/anomie and sustain social order.

questions.question: What does it mean that social structure and people's actions shape each other? How does that explain why societies stay the same or change?

options.A: Social structure limits choices and expectations. People repeat actions that keep the structure stable. If many people change actions or rethink norms, the pattern can shift and a new structure can form.
options.B: Social structure only comes from people's actions and cannot limit future behavior. Change happens only when many people together change their preferences.
options.C: People's actions create structure, but once it exists it no longer affects later behavior.
options.D: Change only comes from top-down rules and policies. Everyday norms and actions do not affect structural change.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in two short sentences. Replaced jargon with simple words and short sentences. Kept the idea that structures and actions affect each other and that widespread action can change structure. Maintained correct answer A.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Structure as both emergent from and determinant of individual action (reciprocal causation)
Concept 2: Multi-level nature of social structure (macro, meso, micro) and cross-level influences (structures, networks, norms, institutions)
Concept 3: Norms and their internalization as a mechanism for sustaining or changing social structure

questions.question: A reciprocity view means people owe each other fair treatment. Why should society use taxes, welfare, and public services to share chances and costs? Why not let private markets decide?

options.A: Because people depend on each other, institutions turn shared duties into laws and services. These give equal access to vital resources and keep cooperation working.
options.B: Because private markets always make perfect fairness. Institutions are not needed.
options.C: Because reciprocity means everyone must have the same outcomes, no matter effort or circumstance.
options.D: Because cultures disagree about duties, so a central power must force one way, ignoring interdependence.

questions.simplification_notes: Explained 'reciprocity' simply, split long sentences, used short simple words, and kept the idea that institutions turn shared duties into protections and equal access.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Social justice as the distribution of wealth, opportunities, and burdens mediated by institutional design (e.g., taxation, social insurance, public services, labor regulation) to achieve equal opportunity.

Concept 2: The ethical foundation of social justice in reciprocity and interdependence within society, including varying cultural emphases on individual responsibility and power, and how these shape justice practices.

Concept 3: The historical-theoretical evolution of social justice (from natural law and early philosophers to modern international law and movements) and how these theories inform contemporary policy and debate.

questions.question: How do pushes and pulls on cells and cell movements work with genes to shape tissues?

options.A: Mechanical forces directly change DNA to create new gene programs that sculpt tissue.
options.B: Cells sense mechanical cues through adhesion proteins and the cytoskeleton. This starts signals that change transcription factors and gene activity, which coordinate migration, adhesion, and contractility to shape tissues.
options.C: Only chemical gradients guide morphogenesis. Mechanical forces do not affect gene control.
options.D: Differentiation sets gene expression first. Mechanical forces act only later after shape is fixed, with no feedback.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simpler words. Kept the main idea that cells sense mechanical cues via adhesion/cytoskeleton, trigger signaling that changes transcription factors and gene activity, and coordinate cell behaviors to shape tissues.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Mechanical forces and cell movement are integral to morphogenesis and are coupled to genetic regulation.
Concept 2: Morphogen gradients guide patterning and differentiation through signaling and receptor interactions.
Concept 3: Gene regulatory networks and master regulatory genes orchestrate cascades of transcriptional events that control cellular behaviors such as migration, adhesion, and contractility.

questions.question: Why does viewing innovation as a set of steps that gives measurable results help organizations? How does this help them handle uncertainty and get more value?

options.A: It says value comes only from the first idea, so later steps are not needed.
options.B: It stresses learning in repeated cycles, so value grows as ideas are tested, improved, and scaled.
options.C: It lets organizations skip market checks until the last stage, saving time.
options.D: It ties value only to a new idea’s novelty and ignores how the idea is carried out.

questions.simplification_notes: Split into two short, simple sentences. Used plain words and active voice. Kept the focus on staged, measurable, and iterative innovation. Options kept plausible and the correct choice unchanged.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Innovation is the practical implementation of ideas that creates value, and it is not solely defined by new invention.
Concept 2: Innovation is a multi-stage process that yields outcomes (new/improved products, services, processes, etc.) and can be seen as both a process and an outcome.
Concept 3: The two-dimensional framework of innovation: degree of novelty (new to firm, market, industry, or world) and kind of innovation (process vs product-service system).

questions.question: In aesthetics, "disinterested pleasure" means enjoying something for its own sake, not for any practical use. How does this work, and why is it useful when judging a work of art?

options.A: It ties judgment to the object's practical usefulness, so the evaluation checks how well the work performs a function.
options.B: It makes us focus on the work's own features, like balance and harmony, not on usefulness or personal goals, so judgments stay less biased.
options.C: It relies on the critic's personal goals to shape the evaluation, making judgments reflect individual aims and desires.
options.D: It makes judgments depend on outside moral or social outcomes instead of the artwork's form or sensory features.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote in short sentences and simple words. Explained 'disinterested pleasure' as enjoying for its own sake. Kept the original meaning and correct answer (B).
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Objectivity vs subjectivity in aesthetic judgments — Can aesthetic judgments be objective, and what leads to disagreements about taste?
Concept 2: Disinterested pleasure as a feature of aesthetic experience — Why is disinterested pleasure important, and how does it detach aesthetic judgment from practical concerns?
Concept 3: The three approaches to aesthetics as a framework — How do concepts/judgments, experiences/responses, and the nature/features of objects relate to each other in studying aesthetics?

questions.question: Some thinkers say all humans share basic mental ideas (psychic unity). Others say each culture shapes these into its own worldview that may not match others. If people share basic ideas but cultures reshape them into different, hard-to-compare forms, what should we expect when we compare cultures?

options.A: If basic ideas are the same, comparisons should show the same cultural outcomes everywhere.
options.B: Basic ideas give a common starting point. Each culture reshapes them into diverse, sometimes hard-to-compare forms. So comparisons can find shared building blocks but must respect meaning differences.
options.C: If worldviews come only from outside influences, shared basic ideas would not matter in comparisons.
options.D: The differences make comparisons impossible and useless.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote sentences in simple words. Broke long sentences into short ones. Kept the idea that shared mental elements and distinct worldviews both matter for comparison.
concepts_tested: The interplay between individual rationality (Enlightenment) and collective creativity (Bildung) as a mechanism shaping culture and cultural identity.
Worldview (Weltanschauung) as a defining structure of culture, including the notion that different groups possess distinct and potentially incommensurable worldviews.
Universal cognitive elements (psychic unity of mankind; elementary ideas) and their tension with cultural particularism in cross-cultural analysis.

questions.question: When profit goals clash with social concerns, how do ethical norms shape a company's choices? What process explains this effect?

options.A: They replace legal rules with voluntary ones, so companies can chase profit without limits.
options.B: They change a company's expected costs and benefits by adding reputation and trust losses, so social concerns become part of decisions.
options.C: They guarantee higher long-term profits by forcing one ethical outcome no matter the market.
options.D: They remove the need for any oversight, because ethics alone will ensure perfect choices.

questions.simplification_notes: Removed technical terms like 'objective function' and 'legitimacy costs'. Used short sentences and simple words like 'costs and benefits', 'reputation', and 'trust'.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: The normative vs. descriptive dimensions of business ethics and how they guide or describe business behavior.
Concept 2: The relationship between profit-maximizing behavior and non-economic (ethical, social) concerns, and how ethical norms mediate or influence corporate decision-making.
Concept 3: Organizational mechanisms for ethical governance (ethics codes, social responsibility charters, ethics regimes) and their role alongside or beyond legal regulation.

questions.question: How does "Creating Shared Value" (CSV) link helping society with making profit?

options.A: By donating profits to charity to build goodwill and a better reputation.
options.B: By changing how it works to solve social problems while lowering costs or entering new markets.
options.C: By following environmental and social reporting rules to avoid fines and penalties.
options.D: By keeping social programs separate from the main business so they do not distract from profit.

questions.simplification_notes: Reduced technical language, used short sentences, removed complex jargon, and kept the core idea that CSV changes business operations to create social benefit and profit.
concepts_tested: Strategic CSR and stakeholder alignment as a driver of firm performance
Creating Shared Value (CSV) as a model linking social impact to profitability
CSR governance mechanisms: self-regulation, ESG reporting, standards, and government incentives

questions.question: In a federal system, how do national and state (or provincial) governments share power and settle disputes? Why is that needed for the country to work?

options.A: Give the national government unlimited power to override state laws in every area, ending state authority and local differences.
options.B: Put the federal constitution above both levels and use a central court to force uniform rules. This can reduce local control.
options.C: Divide powers into exclusive (only national), concurrent (shared), and residual (leftover to states) categories. Use independent courts or tribunals to settle disputes. This keeps national unity while protecting local self-rule.
options.D: Let states keep complete sovereignty and be free from federal rules. This gives strong local control but causes coordination problems.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simple words. Explained exclusive, concurrent, and residual briefly. Kept the idea that courts settle disputes to balance national unity and local autonomy.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Allocation and hierarchy of governmental powers (separation of powers and federal vs. unitary structures)
Concept 2: Sources of constitutional rules (codified vs. uncodified constitutions; role of conventions, statutes, customary law, and international law)
Concept 3: Rights and limits on government action (how constitutions grant powers like taxation/spending while also protecting individual rights)

questions.question: How does the rule of law stop leaders from using power unfairly? How do constitutionalism and the Rechtsstaat help make it work?

options.A: By letting leaders change laws case by case to reach political goals, with few limits from institutions.
options.B: By making the same laws apply to everyone, even leaders, and by having steady rules and independent courts that check power. Constitutionalism and the Rechtsstaat create those legal limits.
options.C: By favouring fast policy changes over steady rules, while constitutionalism and the Rechtsstaat try to keep the law fixed.
options.D: By saying laws count only if leaders or the majority agree, with no independent checks or rights protections.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote into short, clear sentences for middle school. Used plain words and active voice. Kept core ideas: equal application of law, stable procedures, independent courts, and the role of constitutionalism/Rechtsstaat.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Equality before the law and nonarbitrary governance as the core principle of the rule of law
Concept 2: Formalist vs. substantivist conceptions, including how laws should be stable, accessible, clear, and how rights and international law broaden the concept
Concept 3: Relationship to other political-legal ideas (rule of law vs rule of man; links to constitutionalism and Rechtsstaat)

questions.question: Legal positivists say 'what law is' and 'what law ought to be' are not necessarily linked. Why do they say this, and what does analytic jurisprudence study about legal validity instead?

options.A: Because legal validity comes from social sources and a shared rule of recognition, not from moral judgment. Analytic jurisprudence studies where laws come from and how officials accept them, not whether laws are moral.
options.B: Because morality fixes the content of law. Analytic jurisprudence must judge laws by ethics to see if they are valid.
options.C: Because there is a single universal moral standard that law must meet. Analytic jurisprudence cannot separate analysis from moral judgment.
options.D: Because law is just an arbitrary command from the sovereign. So normative questions are irrelevant to legal analysis.

questions.simplification_notes: Made sentences short and simple, removed heavy jargon, explained 'rule of recognition' as how officials accept laws, and kept the original idea that positivism ties validity to social sources not morality.
concepts_tested: The analytic vs normative (and natural law vs legal positivism) debate about whether law and what it ought to be are necessarily connected, shaping how we study law.
The normative function of law: what the law should do, which acts to sanction, and what punishments are permitted, reflecting the purpose and moral/political foundations of law.
Law as a social institution: how jurisprudence analyzes law in light of social scientific knowledge, including cross-cultural variation and empirical study (sociological and experimental approaches).

questions.question: Why does natural law say human-made laws get their legitimacy from universal moral rules discovered by reason? Why not from custom or simply the ruler's command?

options.A: Because reason finds universal moral rules in human nature. These rules give an objective basis for law. Laws that follow them are valid; those that break them are illegitimate.
options.B: Because natural law says law is only what the ruler commands, no matter its moral value.
options.C: Because natural law says morality is just custom that changes over time, so any enforced law is legitimate.
options.D: Because natural law equates law with written rules alone and claims enforcement makes them legitimate.

questions.simplification_notes: Simplified vocabulary and sentence structure. Broke the question into two short sentences. Kept the core idea that reason and human nature give laws their legitimacy. Distractors were simplified but kept plausible.
concepts_tested: Natural law consists of inherent, universal moral standards that can be discovered through reason, grounding intrinsic human rights.

Natural law provides a relationship to positive law by undergirding and informing human-made laws, and it has been used to justify political theories (e.g., social contract) and rights, in opposition to legal positivism.

The historical development and transmission of natural law across thinkers and eras (from ancient philosophers to Aquinas to the Enlightenment) shape its conceptual role in modern rights theory and jurisprudence.

questions.question: How does social capital turn trust and expectations of help into lasting cooperation that makes public goods? How does this work in diverse groups?

options.A: By using formal punishments that stop people from cheating better than informal rules.
options.B: By making people's choices match shared rules so they expect help back. This lowers the cost of working together and lets groups cooperate even if official rules are weak.
options.C: By putting power in one trusted leader who tells the group what to do.
options.D: By pushing members to chase their own private gains unless strict controls force them to cooperate.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the question into two short sentences. Replaced academic phrases with plain words. Broke option B into two clear sentences but kept its meaning. Kept the correct answer the same.
concepts_tested: Social capital as productive networks built on interpersonal relationships, shared identity, norms, and trust that enable cooperative action and generate public goods.
Mechanisms by which social capital affects outcomes (e.g., performance in diverse groups, entrepreneurial firms, managerial performance, supply chain relations) through cooperation and reciprocity.

The broader, historical/philosophical grounding of social capital (associational life, democracy, debates about modernization) as a conceptual framework linking social structure to collective outcomes.

questions.question: How do probabilistic network models like Erdős–Rényi graphs or $p^{*}$ models help us predict how real networks behave?

options.A: They guarantee an exact copy of a real network if we have enough past edge data.
options.B: They use simple probability rules to make edges. These rules produce predictable global features like degree patterns and connectivity, so we can make predictions from limited information.
options.C: They assume all edges are fully decided by node traits and remove any randomness from edge formation.
options.D: They need exact records of every past edge to correctly forecast future links.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in short sentences and plain words for middle school readers. Kept the examples (Erdős–Rényi, $p^{*}$) and the core idea that probabilistic rules give predictable global properties. Made all answer choices plausible but kept the original correct choice.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Networks as relational structures composed of nodes and edges, enabling representation and analysis of complex phenomena across disciplines.

Concept 2: Graph-theoretic and probabilistic frameworks (e.g., Erdős–Rényi random graphs, network probability models, p*) as mechanisms to model edge formation and network properties to support predictive modeling.

Concept 3: Multidisciplinary evolution of network science (from graph theory to sociograms to predictive network models) showing how theories from mathematics, physics, computer science, statistics, and sociology coalesce to study complex networks.

questions.question: If adult animals face a higher chance of dying, why do they spend energy to reproduce earlier instead of keep growing? Which mechanism explains this shift?

options.A: They are less likely to survive to breed later, so delaying gives fewer offspring. Reproducing earlier can make more offspring over a lifetime when survival is low.
options.B: High adult death makes animals grow more before they reproduce. This assumes bigger animals always make more babies.
options.C: Limited resources force animals to use one fixed plan for growth, reproduction, and survival. Mortality risk does not change this plan.
options.D: High death rates reduce selection pressure on reproduction. So animals grow longer and delay having babies.

questions.simplification_notes: Made language simple and direct for middle school. Broke ideas into short sentences. Replaced technical terms with plain words and kept the trade-off and survival probability idea.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Allocation trade-offs across growth, reproduction, and survival shaped by the physical and ecological environment (why/how environment influences resource allocation to different life-history demands).

Concept 2: Timing of key life events (e.g., maturation age, first reproduction, parental investment, senescence) is driven by optimizing evolutionary fitness under ecological constraints (why/how ecological conditions alter life-history schedules).

Concept 3: The use of models and cross-generational fitness measures (genetic and phenotypic approaches) to generate testable predictions about life-history evolution (how models help explain and predict life-history outcomes).

questions.question: In the balance-of-power idea, stability comes from each side's relative strength and limits. Why is this true instead of one side's total power deciding the outcome?

options.A: Because being seen as legitimate always equals having total power. The stronger side can force the weaker.
options.B: Because the total power in a system stays fixed. One side's gain must reduce the other's power.
options.C: Because each side's ability to force or stop actions depends on the other side's ability to resist. Outcomes come from these mutual limits.
options.D: Because institutions can completely protect power from change. Outcomes then stay the same no matter relative strength.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question into two short sentences. Replaced jargon with simple words like 'side', 'limits', and 'force'. Kept the original idea that stability comes from how actors constrain each other. Maintained correct answer C.
concepts_tested: Power as relational and diffuse (including structural and discursive forms; legitimacy of authority)
Classification of power tactics (soft vs hard, rational vs nonrational, unilateral vs bilateral) and how contexts/personality influence use
Balance of power as a relational constraint framework (relative strengths, stability, and constraint rather than absolute power)

questions.question: In group tasks, the group's answer is often better than any single person. Which reason best explains the idea that the whole is greater than its parts?

options.A: Members share different bits of information. Putting these bits together reduces personal mistakes and bias, so the group's answer can beat any one person.
options.B: The group just follows the idea of the loudest or most vocal person, ignoring other views.
options.C: The group reaches the average of everyone's answers and does not create anything new.
options.D: People work less hard in groups (social loafing), which makes the group's work worse.

questions.simplification_notes: Made sentences short and simple, used plain words, explained 'emergent property' as 'whole is greater than its parts', kept the original correct answer and concepts.
concepts_tested: Emergent properties of groups (holism): group behavior and qualities that cannot be deduced from individuals alone.
Group-level mechanisms/forces: positive and negative forces within groups that shape behavior (e.g., status, reciprocity, ostracism, leadership, group decision).
Intergroup relations and social regulation mechanisms: how groups manage cooperation, accountability, and conflict (identifying cheaters, altruism, intergroup dynamics).

questions.question: Why are property rights not absolute, and how does the rule of law allow limits while keeping those limits fair and lawful?

options.A: Because owning property is only a private wish with no public role, so the state can revoke it at any time.
options.B: Because property rights protect people from having property unfairly taken, but are not absolute. States may regulate, tax, or take property for real public needs if they follow the law, act only when necessary, and pay fair compensation.
options.C: Because the state must always take property whenever it sees a public need, without any legal process.
options.D: Because only companies (legal persons) have property rights; individual people do not.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the original complex question into two short sentences. Replaced technical phrases like 'arbitrary deprivation' with 'having property unfairly taken'. Used simple words and short sentences. Kept core ideas about lawful limits, public interest, necessity, and compensation.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: The right to property comprises the entitlement to own property (individually or in association) and protection against arbitrary deprivation.
Concept 2: Property rights are not absolute; they may be limited by public interest through mechanisms like regulations, taxation, and nationalisation.

Concept 3: The scope and status of property rights are contested and vary by context, including which entities qualify as holders (individuals vs. corporations) and which kinds of property are protected, across different international instruments and regions.

questions.question: How do privacy laws help stop invasions and let people get justice? Why are they stronger than social rules or company policies?

options.A: They create rules people must follow. They give ways to punish violators and let people seek redress when harmed.
options.B: They guarantee no invasion can ever happen because everyone will always follow the law.
options.C: They rely only on social norms, so written laws are not needed.
options.D: They apply only to online data and do not protect bodily or physical privacy.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in two short sentences using simple words. Kept the idea that laws both deter wrongs and provide formal remedies. Made each option short and plausible.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Privacy as control of personal information and bodily integrity, enabling selective self-expression.
Concept 2: The relationship between privacy, security, and legal rights (invasions, protections enshrined in laws/constitutions).
Concept 3: Digital privacy as an extension of privacy concepts, including technological protections (encryption, anonymity) and methods of intrusion.

questions.question: According to Thomas More, why should a statesman have knowledge, skill, and personal goodness together? How does each help turn ideas into fair, working government?

options.A: Knowledge gives a clear understanding. Skill helps leaders use that knowledge in real situations. Personal goodness gives moral rightness and public trust. Together they make choices smart, doable, and accepted, and they lower the chance of bad policy, poor execution, or selfish rule.
options.B: Knowledge alone is enough; the other two parts are not needed.
options.C: Personal goodness alone is enough; knowledge and skill are not needed.
options.D: Skill alone is enough; knowledge and goodness will follow from a leader's charm.

questions.simplification_notes: Made language simple and direct. Broke ideas into short sentences. Kept More's three parts and each part's role in turning theory into practical, legitimate government. Answer key unchanged.
concepts_tested: The triad of science, art, and personal virtue as elements of effective statesmanship (More’s perspective)
Narrow vs. broad conceptions of statecraft: managing interstate relations for national advantage vs. studying states and governance more broadly
Statecraft as a contested, interdisciplinary concept linking theory (philosophical ideas) and practice (public diplomacy, governance, leadership)

questions.question: Why do political systems push changes in who gets resources and status to happen by talks and laws? Why not by one side using force?

options.A: Because rules limit actions and make deals and laws stable and accepted. Force risks anger, revenge, and chaos.
options.B: Because force is always illegal and never helps redistribute resources.
options.C: Because negotiations and laws are always the most efficient way to help everyone.
options.D: Because elections alone automatically move resources, so other methods are not needed.

questions.simplification_notes: Turned the question into two short sentences. Replaced complex words like 'legitimacy' and 'destabilization' with 'accepted', 'anger', and 'chaos'. Kept the idea that rules make negotiation and lawmaking more stable and less risky than force.
concepts_tested: Politics as power relations and collective decision-making that determine the distribution of resources and status
Political systems as frameworks that define acceptable methods and constrain or enable political action
Mechanisms of political action (negotiation, lawmaking, party organization, elections, use of force) and how they interact to produce political change

questions.question: How do strategic thinking and strategic planning work together? How do they make a better strategy and then put it into action?

options.A: Strategic thinking gives a fixed list of actions. Strategic planning changes them during work.
options.B: Strategic thinking creates ideas and hypotheses about why and how things could work. Strategic planning turns chosen ideas into concrete actions with timelines and resources.
options.C: Strategic planning creates new options and scenarios. Strategic thinking then evaluates and carries out the chosen plan.
options.D: They are the same, so one can replace the other without any effect.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Split complex ideas into two sentences. Kept the idea that thinking makes hypotheses and planning turns ideas into actions.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Strategic thinking prioritizes asks "Why" and "How" over "What," shaping decisions through reasoning, analysis, and synthesis rather than mere description.
Concept 2: Strategic thinking and strategic planning are distinct but complementary processes; both are needed and interact to improve strategy and execution.
Concept 3: Foresight and collaborative group thinking expand possibility space and generate diverse perspectives, contributing to proactive dialogue and competitive advantage.

questions.question: Why keep governance separate from management? Governance sets strategy and rules at the top. Management runs the daily work. How does this help turn big goals into frontline actions?

options.A: Governance directly turns strategy into daily frontline tasks, so work happens faster.
options.B: Management sets strategy and policy and watches outcomes across the whole organization.
options.C: Governance sets strategy and makes leaders answer for results. Management turns strategy into actions, coordinates daily work, and uses feedback to improve strategy.
options.D: There is no real difference. Both levels do the same tasks.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the question into short sentences. Used simple words and active voice. Kept the idea that governance sets strategy and ensures accountability, while management implements plans and uses feedback.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Hierarchical structure of management and the flow of strategic goals from senior to line management (how goals/policies are translated into frontline actions).
Concept 2: Distinction between governance and management (what senior management does in setting strategy/policy versus directing and implementing through subordinates).
Concept 3: Management as an interdisciplinary, practice-informed field (the relationship between theory, education, and evidence-based management).

questions.question: Why do cultural norms guide what people should do in a group, and how do these norms stay stable?

options.A: People watch others and copy actions that get praise or avoid punishment. They learn the social rewards and costs, so breaking norms lowers social standing and most people conform.
options.B: Because norms are written laws that force people to act the same in every situation.
options.C: Because norms come from fixed genes that make people follow group rules.
options.D: Because norms only describe what people do and do not cause people to change their behavior.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question and answers using short sentences and simple words. Removed technical terms like 'enculturation' and 'socialization' but kept the idea that people learn norms by watching rewards and punishments. Kept incorrect answers plausible.
concepts_tested: Cultural transmission through social learning (enculturation and socialization) as the mechanism by which individuals acquire culture
Norms as templates for acceptable conduct and social expectations that shape behavior
Cultural change dynamics: internal forces and external contact leading to repositioning or transformation of culture

questions.question: How is cultural transmission different from genetic transmission? What is the main result for how fast cultural traits can spread in a group?

options.A: Cultural transmission is only passed from parent to child and is slow, just like genes.
options.B: Cultural transmission can spread sideways between people and from non-parents to younger people. This lets ideas move fast and build on earlier ideas, while genes mostly pass down from parents and follow generations.
options.C: Cultural transmission needs sexual reproduction to spread, so it cannot move faster than genes.
options.D: Cultural transmission and genetic transmission happen at the same speed and face the same selection pressures.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the question into two short sentences. Replaced technical terms (horizontal, oblique, generation-bound) with simpler phrases like “sideways” and “from non-parents to younger people.” Kept the contrast between fast, non-genetic spread of culture and mostly parent-to-child genetic inheritance. Made all options short and plausible.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Distinction and interaction between biological evolution and cultural evolution, including their different transmission mechanisms (genes vs. cultural information).
Concept 2: Use of cultural-transmission models and cladistics as methodological approaches to study cultural evolution.
Concept 3: Interdisciplinary integration, combining archaeology, primatology, genetics, psychology, and other fields to build a coherent picture of human evolution.

questions.question: What changes when we see human–computer interaction as a back-and-forth talk between a person and a computer? How does that view affect design choices and how we judge user satisfaction?

options.A: It makes designers cut down user input and use fixed, pre-set task steps.
options.B: It says users and the system shape the interaction together. So designs must let users explore, adapt to changing goals, and use repeated feedback to improve satisfaction.
options.C: It means there is one best way for everyone to interact, so we can use one simple test.
options.D: It says satisfaction should be measured only by speed and task completion, not by understanding or learnability.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the original complex sentence into two simple questions. Replaced 'open-ended dialogue' with 'back-and-forth talk'. Shortened and clarified options using simple words and short sentences. Kept the original idea that interaction is shaped jointly and needs adaptive, iterative design and evaluation.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Interaction as an open-ended dialogue between human and computer, shaping how design decisions influence use and satisfaction.
Concept 2: Multimodal interaction channels (visual, auditory, tactile) as mechanisms that enable and constrain how users communicate with systems.
Concept 3: Interdisciplinary foundation and the design–evaluation–implementation lifecycle, showing how knowledge from multiple fields informs the creation and assessment of interactive systems.

questions.question: How does making and testing many quick prototypes help designers learn and build a working solution?

options.A: Each test only proves the first idea was right, so designers stick to the original plan.
options.B: Each round shows hidden assumptions, gives real user feedback, and lets designers reframe the problem to improve the solution.
options.C: Prototyping mainly speeds up production by packing all requirements into the first version.
options.D: Iteration forces a strict step-by-step order and stops big changes after the first problem framing.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Removed technical terms like 'abductive reasoning' and 'co-evolution'. Kept the idea that iteration reveals assumptions, gathers user feedback, and allows reframing to improve the solution.
concepts_tested: Wicked problems and design thinking: why design thinking is suited to ill-defined/wicked problems and how it differs from solving well-defined problems.
Iterative, non-linear process with prototyping and user testing: how iteration drives learning and solution development.
Abductive and productive reasoning as core cognitive mechanisms: how these reasoning modes contribute to generating creative, viable design solutions.

questions.question: How does understanding how users think about a product help a UX designer test a design?

options.A: It helps designers form testable guesses about users' goals and actions and check them with user tests.
options.B: It makes the designer focus only on how things look.
options.C: It removes the need to run usability tests.
options.D: It makes designers rely only on their own opinions.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in simpler words ("understanding how users think" instead of "empathy with users' mental models" and "test" instead of "validate"). Shortened options and used plain language while keeping the original meaning.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Research and data drive design decisions in UX design, rather than relying on aesthetic preferences.
Concept 2: UX design is holistic, covering all aspects of the user’s perceived experience (usability, usefulness, desirability, brand perception, performance) and not limited to the interface.

Concept 3: UX design draws on multiple disciplines (HCI, UCD, IA, visual design, etc.) and relies on empathy and understanding of users’ needs and mental models to shape and validate design decisions.

questions.question: How can epigenetic states be kept the same after a cell divides, even though the DNA sequence does not change?

options.A: Because the DNA sequence mutates in daughter cells so it matches the parent's gene activity.
options.B: Because maintenance enzymes copy DNA methylation patterns onto the new DNA strand during replication. Also, modified histones from the parent help rebuild chromatin states in the daughter cells.
options.C: Because transcription factors bind permanently to promoters and fix gene activity in every daughter cell.
options.D: Because epigenetic marks are erased every cell cycle and must be re-made from scratch for each new cell.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simple words. Kept key mechanisms: DNA methylation maintenance and parental histone-guided re-establishment. Made all options plausible but kept correct answer B.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Epigenetic regulation alters gene expression without changing the DNA sequence, using mechanisms such as DNA methylation, histone modification, and non-coding RNAs.

Concept 2: Epigenetic states can be stably inherited through cell divisions and may persist across generations, linking environmental and developmental influences to long-term gene expression patterns.
Concept 3: Epigenetics drives cellular differentiation during development by activating some genes and repressing others to form distinct cell types.

questions.question: Why must universal-design projects make trade-offs and pick priorities? How do designers decide what to focus on?

options.A: They assume a perfect solution can meet every need if resources were unlimited, so trade-offs are not needed.
options.B: They face many different and sometimes conflicting needs with limited resources. Designers focus on fixing the biggest barriers and changes that help the most people.
options.C: They may leave out rare, low-impact features to make things easier for most users. They justify this by aiming to help the largest number of people.
options.D: They leave choices to designers' opinions, thinking experts know best. This claim justifies trade-offs by authority, not by users' needs.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the question into two short sentences. Used simple words and short sentences. Kept the idea that diverse needs and limited resources force prioritizing high-impact solutions.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Universal design aims to maximize usability for the greatest number of people by removing barriers and enabling participation.
Concept 2: Inclusion-oriented design involves trade-offs and prioritization, recognizing dilemmas when designing for diverse needs.

Concept 3: Universal design emerges from barrier-free design and accessibility movements and requires interdisciplinary collaboration (engineering, architecture, medicine) with socio-material implications.

questions.question: Settler colonialism aims to replace Indigenous peoples with settlers. How does that goal change how governments are set up and why does that change last longer than other colonial types?

options.A: It preserves some Indigenous authority within the colonizer's legal system. This leads to shared, lasting governance with settlers.
options.B: It replaces Indigenous authority with settler authority. It builds state institutions around taking land and 'civilizing' ideas. This makes settler control last long after direct rule ends.
options.C: It concentrates power in companies and resource takers. It leaves Indigenous political institutions mostly intact.
options.D: It sets up temporary administrative units that end after formal decolonization. Therefore government change is only short-term.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences, simpler words, and removed technical terms like 'coloniality' and 'biopolitics'. Kept the main idea that settler colonialism aims to replace Indigenous people and that this makes state institutions and domination more lasting.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Coloniality and biopolitics as mechanisms of domination (how beliefs in superiority, civilizing missions, and the resulting racialized/gender/class hierarchies sustain colonization and subordinate colonized peoples)

Concept 2: Forms of colonialism and their structural differences (settler colonialism aiming to supplant Indigenous peoples vs. other forms; the idea of organizing colonized peoples into separate colonies; neocolonialism as indirect continuation)

Concept 3: Long-term impacts and processes (how colonial institutions influence modern economic development, regime types, and state capacity; the role of decolonization waves in shaping postcolonial trajectories)

questions.question: Why do ideas from the dominant group often seem 'natural' to people from different backgrounds? Which main process makes these ideas feel normal?

options.A: Because people naturally come to the same views. They have a shared human psychology.
options.B: Because the state forces uniform meanings through punishment. This leaves no room for subcultures.
options.C: Because institutions like schools, media, religion, and law spread ideas that tie meanings to who has power. These ideas shape what people accept as 'common sense'. People can resist, but resistance stays inside power limits.
options.D: Because global technology removes local differences. It forces a single global culture.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simpler words. Replaced academic terms (e.g., hegemony) with clear phrases like 'schools, media, religion, and law' and 'tie meanings to who has power'. Kept the idea that institutions create consent and that resistance exists.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Culture as a power-laden, meaning-generating process (how cultural practices relate to ideology, class, nation, and other social forces; how meaning is produced, disseminated, and contested).
Concept 2: Culture as dynamic and processual (cultures are interacting, changing sets of practices rather than fixed entities).

Concept 3: Interdisciplinary frameworks and mechanisms (use of multiple theoretical approaches including Marxism, semiotics, feminist theory, postcolonialism; ideas like cultural hegemony and agency; globalization as a context for cultural analysis).

questions.question: Non-reductive physicalism says mental states depend on the brain but are not the same as brain states. How can a belief cause a physical action under this view?

options.A: Because mental states are the same as brain states, so mental causes are just physical causes.
options.B: Because mental states are defined by their role and depend on brain states, they can cause actions without being identical to brain states.
options.C: Because mental states have no causal power; behavior is driven only by physical brain processes.
options.D: Because the mind is a separate substance that directly acts on the body to produce actions.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simple words. Replaced technical term 'supervene' with 'depend on'. Kept the idea that functional role plus dependence lets mental states cause actions without reduction.
concepts_tested: The mind–body relationship: distinctness vs. unity of mind and body and whether they can causally interact
Competing theoretical frameworks: dualism, physicalism/monism, idealism, functionalism, property dualism, non-reductive theories
Mental causation and agency: how mental states (beliefs, desires) causally influence physical actions and implications for free will and moral responsibility

questions.question: Why should we evaluate and rank risks before deciding how to reduce them?

options.A: Because resources are limited, so we focus on risks with highest chance and biggest harm to reduce overall risk most.
options.B: Because evaluating risks makes sure every risk is fixed the same way no matter how bad it is.
options.C: Because ranking risks lets you delay the biggest dangers until you have more resources.
options.D: Because after you rank risks there is no need to keep watching them.

questions.simplification_notes: Changed formal wording to short, simple sentences. Removed technical terms and long clauses. Kept the idea that limited resources mean focusing on high-probability and high-impact risks.
concepts_tested: The risk management process: identification, evaluation, prioritization, followed by minimization, monitoring, and control of risks.
Risk treatment strategies and the risk–opportunity relationship: avoidance, reduction, transfer, and retention for threats, with opposite considerations for opportunities.
Standards and professional roles shaping practice: influence of organizations (PMI, NIST, ISO, actuarial societies) and roles like risk manager and risk analyst across contexts.

questions.question: If risk is the 'effect of uncertainty on objectives', why can risk be both good and bad, and what should we do about it?

options.A: Because uncertainty is always bad, so we should only try to stop things from getting worse.
options.B: Because uncertainty can push results above or below our goals, so we should find opportunities and reduce threats.
options.C: Because risk only means the chance of loss, managers should focus only on lowering losses.
options.D: Because objectives never change when things are uncertain, risk does not matter for decisions.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and used simple words. Replaced 'deviation from the expected' with 'push results above or below our goals'. Kept core idea that risk can be positive or negative and management should seek opportunities and limit threats.
concepts_tested: Risk as the effect of uncertainty on objectives (deviation from expected; can be positive or negative)
Components of risk (risk sources, potential events, their consequences, and their likelihood)
Cross-domain application of risk management principles (ISO 31000 guidance) and the idea that risk management involves principles and processes, not just definitions

questions.question: How can environmental changes, like cutting forests or climate shifts, change disease risk? How do they change how we should treat people and animals?

options.A: Because they change how people, animals, and pathogens meet, so we need shared surveillance and cross-sector work.
options.B: Because environmental changes only affect wild animals and do not change human disease risk.
options.C: Because doctors pick treatments by human rules only, with no need to consider animals or the environment.
options.D: Because environmental changes always lower pathogen numbers and so we do not need joint health actions.

questions.simplification_notes: Split into two short questions, used simple words and examples (cutting forests, climate shifts), removed technical jargon, and made each option short and clear.

questions.question: Why does random assignment let us say a result was caused by the treatment? How does it let us use p-values?

options.B: It guarantees treatment effects exist, so p-values always prove real effects.
options.C: It makes the groups similar on average for both known and unknown factors. That means differences we see likely come from the treatment. P-values then tell how unlikely those differences are if there was no effect.
options.D: It removes all experimental errors, so p-values become exact measures.

concepts_tested: The design of experiments and statistical inference as foundational principles for how biological data are collected, analyzed, and interpreted.
The integration of statistics with genetics and evolution to form population genetics and the modern evolutionary synthesis (conceptual link between disciplines).
The use of foundational statistical tools (e.g., ANOVA, p-values, Fisher’s exact test) as mechanisms enabling testing and interpretation of biological hypotheses.

questions.question: Why do policies that change things like housing, jobs, and income reduce health gaps? Why is that better than programs that only try to change people's habits?

Concept 2: Population health shifts focus from individual-level factors to population-level determinants and policies/interventions to improve health.

questions.question: Mass media often sends one message from one producer to many people in different places and times. How does the split between making and receiving content explain both its wide reach and its weak feedback or customization?

options.D: It guarantees instant distribution with no delay, so audiences get content as soon as it is made and feedback stays perfect.

questions.simplification_notes: Removed technical terms and long clauses. Broke ideas into short sentences. Kept the idea that making content in one place helps wide reach but limits quick, local feedback.
