questions.question: Rule-consequentialism says we should follow rules chosen for their good results. Why follow a rule if one case would give a better result by doing something else?

options.A: Because judging every action needs hard outcome predictions and can fail. A good rule gives more net good over time.
options.B: Because the rule itself has moral worth that stands apart from its outcomes.
options.C: Because people like simple rules and so follow them even when results are worse.
options.D: Because following the rule always gives immediate rewards in every situation.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences, used simple words, split complex ideas into short lines. Kept the main idea that rules can reduce prediction error and produce better overall outcomes.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: The principle that the rightness of an act is determined by its consequences (outcome-based evaluation and balance of good over evil).
Concept 2: The goods that count for evaluating consequences (pleasure, absence of pain, preference satisfaction, or a broader general good) and how different definitions shape judgments.

Concept 3: The relationships and potential compatibilities between consequentialism and other ethical frameworks (deontology, virtue ethics, pragmatic ethics), including examples of how they might overlap or be reconciled (e.g., rule-consequentialism, rights justified by consequences).

questions.question: In adaptive management, why should managers treat actions as repeated experiments with monitoring and feedback? How does this help when we do not know how nature will respond?

options.A: It puts all decision power in one central authority so rules stay the same everywhere.
options.B: It creates a learning loop where results update models and guide future actions, lowering uncertainty over time.
options.C: It cuts data collection to save money and relies on experts to decide every choice.
options.D: It assumes nature is fully predictable, so managers never change their first forecasts.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in short, simple sentences. Replaced 'iterative' with 'repeated' and 'ongoing monitoring and feedback' with plain terms. Kept the core idea that adaptive management is a learning loop that reduces uncertainty.
concepts_tested: Integrated, systems-based approach that links ecological health with human livelihoods and long-term sustainability.
Adaptive management as a learning-based mechanism to adjust policies and practices in response to uncertainty and changing conditions.
Governance and ownership regimes (e.g., state property, Indigenous land rights) shaping how resources are used, governed, and maintained.

questions.question: How does the central executive help people solve problems when tasks or rules change?

options.A: It works like a passive storage box that lets information sit in working memory without organizing it.
options.B: It pulls information from long-term memory and guides changing items in working memory to reach goals.
options.C: It puts all new input straight into long-term memory without using working memory or retrieval.
options.D: It says mental growth happens only in fixed stages and plays no part in online thinking.

questions.simplification_notes: Made sentences shorter and used simpler words. Kept the idea that the central executive coordinates retrieval from long-term memory and manipulation in working memory to support flexible, goal-directed action. Contrasted this with passive storage, direct long-term encoding, and stage-only views.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: The information processing sequence and the roles of attention, working memory, encoding, and long-term memory in transforming input into output.
Concept 2: The central executive as the control system that coordinates retrieval and manipulation of information across working and long-term memory.
Concept 3: The continuous development view, where cognitive maturation changes processing components over time, contrasting with stage-based theories like Piaget’s.

questions.question: Why should we study science and medicine in their history and culture? Why not treat them as neutral, universal products?

options.A: Because the same technology can have different effects and meanings. Power, institutions, and daily use shape its development and outcomes.
options.B: Because once a technology is built, its effects depend only on its technical parts.
options.C: Because social context only decides who pays for research, not how people actually use technologies.
options.D: Because ethics alone drives technology, and society does not shape technical choices.

questions.simplification_notes: Split the question into two short sentences. Replaced academic terms with simple words. Shortened and clarified each option while keeping their original ideas.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Science and technology are socially embedded enterprises whose development and consequences are shaped by historical, cultural, and social contexts.
Concept 2: The critique of technological determinism and the use of contextual, historically informed analyses (including gender and power dynamics) to understand science and medicine.

Concept 3: The interdisciplinary nature of STS, integrating anthropology, history, political science, sociology, etc., to study the creation, development, diffusion, and societal impacts of science and technology, including theoretical frameworks like paradigm shifts (Kuhn).

questions.question: Why might a government agency's service contract be treated as private law instead of public law?

options.A: Because the core activities, participants, and goals match a private business deal, so private law applies.
options.B: Because just having a government agency involved always makes it public law.
options.C: Because private law never applies when the state takes part.
options.D: Because government agencies are always immune from private contracts.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in simple words, used short sentences, removed legal jargon, and kept the idea that classification depends on activity, participants, and purpose. Distractors remain plausible but incorrect.
concepts_tested: Rule of law and judicial oversight: government authorities must act within the law, with citizens able to seek judicial review to challenge decisions.
Functional boundary between public and private law: classification is based on domain and purpose, not merely on factual division, with blurred lines in practice.
Relationship-centric governance: public law governs asymmetric relationships between the state and individuals and among state institutions, shaping rights, duties, and remedies.

questions.question: From quantum mechanics, why does forming a chemical bond release energy? How does spreading electrons between atoms change the system's energy?

options.A: When atoms share electrons, the electrons spread into a larger molecular orbital. Being more spread out lowers their average kinetic energy and stabilizes the bond by delocalization.
options.B: The energy comes only from stronger attraction between electrons and nuclei. The electrons' kinetic energy does not change.
options.C: Bonding cuts electron–electron repulsion by pushing electrons closer to each nucleus. This lowers potential energy without changing kinetic energy.
options.D: Electrons get more tightly trapped between the nuclei, so their kinetic energy rises. A larger drop in potential energy more than makes up for this, so the bond is stable.

questions.simplification_notes: Language simplified to short sentences and everyday words. Quantum idea kept: electrons spread out into a molecular orbital, lowering kinetic energy and stabilizing the bond. Distractors kept plausible.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Quantum-mechanical stabilization and energy reasons for bond formation (why bond formation releases energy and how electron distribution lowers the system's energy, including the role of kinetic energy and orbital delocalization).
Concept 2: Balance of attractive and repulsive forces sets bond length and strength (how bond distance is determined by competing interactions and why an optimal distance exists).

Concept 3: Multiple theoretical frameworks explain bonding (how valence bond theory, molecular orbital theory, hybridization, resonance, and simplified models like the octet rule/VSEPR provide different but complementary explanations of bonds).

questions.question: Why do simple computer models help scientists learn things that are hard to see from direct measurements?

options.A: Because computer models always include every molecular detail, so they predict everything correctly.
options.B: Because building a model makes scientists pick key causal links. They can change variables in a controlled way and study system-wide behaviors that may hide in real data.
options.C: Because simulations replace the need for real experiments and give answers faster.
options.D: Because models mainly act as data storage, so researchers need fewer experiments.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences, used simple words, removed technical terms, and focused on the core idea that models highlight key interactions and let researchers test causes.
concepts_tested: Interdisciplinary integration of computer science, mathematics, and biology as a foundational principle driving the field
Modeling and computational simulations as core mechanisms for understanding biological systems
Data growth and the resulting need for new computational methods as a driving relationship in the field’s development

questions.question: A drug can bind very tightly to its receptor. Why does that not always make it work well in a real body? How do pharmacokinetics (how the body handles a drug) and pharmacodynamics (how the drug affects the body) together decide the result?

options.A: Because tight receptor binding always makes a drug work well, even if the body breaks it down quickly.
options.B: Because both how much drug reaches the target (pharmacokinetics) and how the receptor responds (pharmacodynamics) matter; high affinity helps, but low exposure or fast clearance can prevent the effect.
options.C: Because pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics act totally separately and do not change receptor occupancy or the drug's effect.
options.D: Because once a drug binds a receptor, the effect is fixed and the body's handling of the drug cannot change how long or how strong the response is.

questions.simplification_notes: Made sentences short and simple. Added quick definitions of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. Kept the idea that high affinity alone is not enough and that both PK and PD set the drug's effect.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Pharmacodynamics vs pharmacokinetics as complementary frameworks that determine a drug's action (PD describes effects on biology; PK describes the body's effects on the drug) and how they together shape therapeutic outcomes.
Concept 2: Drug-receptor interactions and signal transduction as the cellular/mechanistic basis for pharmacodynamic effects.
Concept 3: ADME (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion) and organismal influences on drug exposure, concentration at targets, and hence efficacy and toxicity.

questions.question: When societies grew from small bands to full states, power became more centralized and hierarchical. How did this change mainly affect their ability to make large public decisions?

options.A: Power spread out, so local groups could try new ideas more. But coordinating big decisions became harder.
options.B: Power concentrated, so leaders could make big decisions more easily. It also raised the risk of big failures and made people doubt leaders.
options.C: It removed the need for rules and institutions. Society then ordered itself without formal government.
options.D: It guaranteed equal sharing of resources across the whole society.

questions.simplification_notes: Made wording shorter and clearer. Replaced technical terms like 'coordination costs' with 'easier to coordinate' and explained 'legitimacy' as people doubting leaders. Broke complex sentences into shorter ones.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Political systems are mechanisms for authoritatively allocating values and making public decisions (Easton’s principle).
Concept 2: Centralization and hierarchical organization (bands, tribes, chiefdoms, states) model how authority and governance structures evolve and influence political power.
Concept 3: Regime types exist on a liberal-democratic to totalitarian spectrum (with hybrids), highlighting how legitimacy, rights, and state control interact within different political arrangements.

questions.question: Why do maps that keep the operations (homomorphisms) let us study groups, rings, and modules with the same language?

options.A: Because homomorphisms keep the operations, what happens before and after the map follows the same rules. This lets us use one kind of map and study constructions like kernels, quotients, and products across many structures.
options.B: Because homomorphisms are always one-to-one and onto, they show all structures are the same after renaming elements.
options.C: Because homomorphisms ignore operations and only tell which elements belong to which set, they reduce algebra to set theory.
options.D: Because homomorphisms can be defined for any structure, even without common rules, they make no general framework.

questions.simplification_notes: Changed formal wording to short, simple sentences. Kept key idea that homomorphisms preserve operations and allow shared constructions (kernels, quotients, products). Removed heavy jargon and long clauses.
concepts_tested: The use of homomorphisms and categories to create a unified framework for analyzing different algebraic structures.
Category theory and universal algebra as high-level frameworks for studying algebraic structures as unified objects or types (e.g., varieties like the variety of groups).
The historical shift to formal axiomatic definitions (groups, rings, fields) that unifies disparate results under common concepts and principles.

questions.question: Why does abstraction work by picking only the features you need? How does that help one idea apply to many different things?

options.A: It keeps all the details so you can copy the exact situation later.
options.B: It keeps only the parts that matter for a purpose. It drops the rest so the same idea fits many examples.
options.C: It turns each experience into a fixed token to memorize everything.
options.D: It makes a strict one-to-one label for each thing, so you cannot use it in other contexts.

questions.simplification_notes: Split into two short sentences, used simple words and active voice, removed technical terms, kept the idea of selective filtering and broad application (type-token example implied).
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Abstraction as selective filtering of information to retain only aspects relevant for a purpose.
Concept 2: Type-token distinction as an example of levels of abstraction (e.g., 'ball' vs. 'leather soccer ball').
Concept 3: Abstraction as a bridge to language and semantics, mapping particular experiences onto general concepts and connecting with metaphor and general semantics.

questions.question: Why does it matter that the capital stock has many different physical and non-physical assets? Output depends on labor $L$ and capital $K$ ($Q=f(L,K)$).

options.A: Any asset can instantly replace any other in providing services, so the asset mix is irrelevant.
options.B: Different assets give different amounts of useful service and wear out at different speeds. So the mix affects total services available over time.
options.C: Intangible assets do not provide productive services and can be ignored.
options.D: Capital and labor are perfect substitutes no matter the asset mix.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Kept the production function $Q=f(L,K)$. Replaced technical phrases like 'depreciation/marginal-product profiles' with 'wear out' and 'give different amounts of useful service.'
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Capital as a produced input that provides productive services over multiple production cycles, distinguishing it from one-time-use inputs.
Concept 2: The capital stock as a heterogeneous pool of tangible and intangible assets that collectively supply capital services.
Concept 3: Capital as a core factor of production alongside labor, represented in production functions (e.g., Q = f(L, K)) where capital (K) interacts with labor (L) to determine output.

questions.question: Hart says a rule of recognition tells people what counts as valid law. Why does this rule let many official statements work together as one legal system, even if some officials disagree?

options.A: Because it gives a common test officials accept to decide what counts as law. People follow rules because of social practice, not each official's personal belief.
options.B: Because it forces everyone to obey one ruler who decides what counts as law.
options.C: Because it makes law depend on one universal moral code that all officials agree is right.
options.D: Because it says all rules must come from one basic norm at the top.

questions.simplification_notes: Changed wording to short sentences and simple words. Kept Hart's idea that a shared social test (rule of recognition) makes diverse official pronouncements function as one system. Kept the alternative views (sovereign rule, moral grounding, basic norm).
concepts_tested: Rule of recognition and legal validity (Hart’s concept of a shared rule that validates legal pronouncements)
Foundational bases of legal systems (sovereignty-based vs. norm-based foundations, e.g., Austin’s sovereign legislator vs. Kelsen’s basic norm)
Legal pluralism and cross-system relationships (overlapping authorities, indigenous/customary laws, federal and international law interactions)

questions.question: Under the goal of minimizing training error, what happens if we increase a model's capacity (make it more complex)? When does more capacity help or make the model worse on new, unseen data?

options.A: It always reduces bias and so it guarantees better performance on new data as the dataset grows.
options.B: It lowers training error but never changes test error, so performance on new data stays the same.
options.C: It can lower training error. But if the model becomes too flexible for the data, it can overfit and do worse on new data. More capacity helps only when you have lots of data or when you use methods that limit complexity (regularization).
options.D: It only changes how fast training finishes, not how well the model predicts on new data.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote in simple sentences. Replaced 'capacity' with 'more complex/flexible'. Explained generalization as performance on new data and kept the overfitting/data-or-regularization trade-off.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Generalization from training data and empirical risk minimization as the core objective of ML.
Concept 2: ML as a synthesis of statistics and optimization, with deep learning (neural networks) as a major subfield that leverages these foundations to improve performance.
Concept 3: Theoretical framework of probably approximately correct (PAC) learning that provides formal, mathematical grounding for describing ML and its relation to empirical risk minimization.

questions.question: Why does pattern recognition pick the most likely label for data? How does using statistics help when data are noisy or vary?

options.A: Because real-world data are noisy and come from a probability distribution. Probability methods combine the likelihood and priors to pick the most plausible label and make results robust.
options.B: Because pattern recognition uses exact template matching and would not tolerate noise or variation.
options.C: Because it only uses unlabeled data and clustering, so it decides labels without prior knowledge.
options.D: Because it can check every possible pattern to find a perfect match and so guarantees no errors.

questions.simplification_notes: Split into short sentences, used simple words, kept key idea that probabilistic methods use likelihood and priors to handle noise.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Inference under uncertainty — pattern recognition aims to assign labels by the most likely match while accounting for statistical variation.
Concept 2: Relationships and distinctions — how pattern recognition relates to, and differs from, related tasks (classification, regression, sequence labeling, parsing) and from pattern matching.
Concept 3: Learning from data — the role of labeled training data, supervised vs unsupervised methods, and the connection to machine learning and data mining.

questions.question: When launching a new product, teams must plan how much to make. How does working together across operations, supply chain, marketing, finance, suppliers, and technology help them meet customer needs?

options.A: Each team focuses only on its own goals, so they reduce conflicts.
options.B: Teams share the same view of demand, process limits, and capabilities. They make synced choices about capacity, inventory, and quality to satisfy customers.
options.C: Marketing can force the production schedule without checking if manufacturing can meet it.
options.D: It guarantees perfect demand forecasts and zero stockouts.

questions.simplification_notes: Split into two short sentences, removed technical jargon, explained capacity planning in plain words, and used simple examples of teams and actions.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Transformation of inputs into outputs with a focus on efficiency and meeting customer requirements (resources, processes, outputs).
Concept 2: The role of design decisions (product design, process design, capacity, facilities, quality management) in shaping operational performance.
Concept 3: Strategic and operational integration, including cross-functional alignment with other functions (supply chains, marketing, finance, HR) and collaboration with suppliers and technology.

questions.question: Different departments in a supply chain must trade off goals to cut total costs. Which choice best explains how this works in real life?

options.A: By making each department only try to meet its own goals. They rely on market incentives to lower total costs.
options.B: By aligning incentives and sharing information. This makes decisions show extra inventory costs (storage or spoilage) and benefits of meeting demand, so choices lower total costs across the chain.
options.C: By removing all buffers and safety stock. This always lowers inventory costs no matter how demand changes.
options.D: By giving one manager all decision power. That manager then dictates planning, buying, making, and shipping for everyone.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Replaced 'marginal' with 'extra'. Gave plain examples (storage, spoilage). Kept the original idea that sharing information and aligning incentives minimizes overall cost.
concepts_tested: End-to-end integration of material, information, and capital flows across planning, sourcing, production, and logistics to synchronize supply with demand and create net value.
Interdepartmental coordination and trade-offs as a mechanism to minimize total supply-chain costs (e.g., balancing inventory levels between sales needs and warehouse cost constraints).
Performance measurement and evolving SCM frameworks (including resilience, sustainability, risk management) as central to monitoring and guiding supply-chain activities.

questions.question: Why do applied researchers change methods because of real-world limits like not using random sampling? Why do they still clearly say what they did and how that affects the results?

options.A: To make sure the study's findings are always correct about the people in the study.
options.B: Because real-life limits can bias results, and explaining methods helps people judge what the results mean and where they apply.
options.C: To make the results true for every place and every person.
options.D: To avoid all bias by using flexible methods.

questions.simplification_notes: Rewrote the question in short, simple sentences. Removed technical terms and long phrases. Kept the core idea: methods change for real-world limits, and clear reporting helps others understand limits and interpretation.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: The primary aim of applied research is to translate existing theories and methods into practical, client- or market-oriented outcomes, distinguishing it from basic/pure research which seeks new theories.

Concept 2: Real-world research requires flexibility in methodology (e.g., may forego random sampling) while maintaining transparency about methods and acknowledging the implications of relaxing strict standards.

Concept 3: There are distinct applied-research types (action research, evaluation research, industrial research, gauging research), each with a specific practical or evaluative purpose (solving issues, informing decisions, creating new goods/services, assessing processes).

questions.question: Why should a company run many different R&D projects when its work is risky and aims for long-term gains?

options.A: It guarantees quick profits from every project and removes the need for long-term planning.
options.B: It spreads risk across many uncertain projects and fits a long-term plan where breakthroughs may happen.
options.C: It makes all projects return money fast, shortening the payback time.
options.D: It puts all resources into one project to make success more certain.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened and rewrote the question and options into simple sentences. Used everyday words and active voice. Kept the idea that R&D is risky, long-term, and benefits from spreading risk.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: R&D as a future-oriented, high-risk activity aimed at developing new products/services, with an uncertain and non-immediate return on investment, enabling long-term competitive advantage.
Concept 2: The link between R&D strategy and market/consumer needs (marketing-driven vs technology-driven development) and how market research and customer needs shape R&D direction.
Concept 3: R&D governance and metrics (R&D intensity, patents, publications), including outsourcing and risk implications for organizations.

questions.question: Why is the scientific method better as a cycle you repeat, not a fixed list of steps?

options.A: It makes scientists follow one single order of steps in every study.
options.B: It says scientists often must go back and change hypotheses, methods, or interpretations when new data or bias appears.
options.C: It claims that after getting results scientists will have no more questions.
options.D: It removes hypothetical reasoning and accepts only direct observation as valid.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened language to middle school level. Emphasized the idea of repeating and revising steps. Kept answer choices plausible and the correct option unchanged.
concepts_tested: Falsifiability as a criterion for a meaningful, testable hypothesis
Iterative, non-linear nature of the method: general principles with variable steps rather than a fixed sequence

Empirical testing cycle: inductive hypothesizing from observations, predicting consequences, testing with experiments/statistics, and revising/discarding hypotheses based on results (with skepticism to mitigate cognitive bias)

questions.question: A particle has electric charge $q$. It moves with velocity $v$ in a region with magnetic field $B$. There is no electric field. Which statement best explains how the magnetic field changes the particle's path, using the Lorentz force law?

options.A: The magnetic field pushes along the velocity. The particle speeds up and keeps moving straight.
options.B: The magnetic field pushes perpendicular to both $v$ and $B$. Its magnitude is $|F| = |q||v||B|\sin(\phi)$, where $\phi$ is the angle between $v$ and $B$. This force changes direction but not speed, causing circular or helical motion.
options.C: The magnetic field takes energy from the particle. Its speed falls and it moves in shrinking circles.
options.D: The magnetic field only acts if the particle is at rest. Moving charges feel no force from $B$.

questions.simplification_notes: Broke the original into short sentences. Used simple words and active voice. Kept the Lorentz force formula $|F|=|q||v||B|\sin(\phi)$ and the idea that the force is perpendicular and changes direction but not speed.
concepts_tested: The unification of electric and magnetic phenomena into a single electromagnetic field and how charges/ currents relate to electric and magnetic fields.
Maxwell's equations as the framework that describe relations between E, B, charges, and currents and predict electromagnetic waves.
The Lorentz force as the microscopic mechanism by which moving charges experience force in electric and magnetic fields, linking field concepts to particle motion.

questions.question: Barnett and Duvall say power works through social relations. It shapes what actors can do and decide. How can power grow even when material resources stay the same?

options.A: By forcing others to obey, using threats or military power to control events.
options.B: By changing actors' identities and social ties so their goals, habits, and abilities match the power holder.
options.C: By persuading others with good arguments so they freely change their minds.
options.D: By getting more physical resources like money and weapons, which directly raises influence.

questions.simplification_notes: Replaced academic wording with short sentences. Broke the definition into two simple lines. Made each option clear and age-appropriate while keeping the original meaning and correct choice.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Power as a social process and social relation that not only yields material advantages but also structures actors’ identities and capacities.
Concept 2: Polarity (unipolar, bipolar, multipolar) as a distribution of power in the international system and its effects on state behavior and inter-state dynamics.

Concept 3: Multiple conceptualizations of power (goal of states/leaders, influence/control outcomes, victory/security, resource/control, status) and the methodological implication that power is production of effects through social relations (as argued by Barnett & Duvall), not mere causality or persuasion.

questions.question: In a closed-loop control system, the controller compares the measured value to the setpoint. It uses the error to change the input. Why does this help keep the process near the setpoint when disturbances happen?

options.A: It increases the input to push the process away from the setpoint so change is faster.
options.B: It uses the error to change the input so the error gets smaller and the process returns to the setpoint.
options.C: It keeps the input constant and relies on disturbances to cancel themselves out.
options.D: It replaces the setpoint with the current measurement so the system matches the present value.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences, used simple words and active voice. Kept the idea of comparing measurement to setpoint and using error to correct disturbances (negative feedback). Made all options plausible.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Closed-loop control and negative feedback maintain a process at its setpoint by comparing sensed values to desired values and correcting input.
Concept 2: Integration of diverse technologies (mechanical, hydraulic, pneumatic, electrical, electronic devices, and computers) to predetermine decisions and embody them in automated systems.
Concept 3: Disturbance rejection and stability as central aims of control theory, enabling automation to function despite disturbances.

questions.question: When scientists put a gene into a different organism, why must they use a promoter the host can read?

options.A: Because promoters from other species never work, and only the host's promoters make the gene work.
options.B: Because the promoter gives places where the cell's RNA-making enzyme and helper proteins attach, so the cell makes RNA.
options.C: Because the promoter changes the gene's codons so the host's protein-making machine can translate it.
options.D: Because only the gene's code matters and regulatory parts do not affect if the gene is read.

questions.simplification_notes: Shortened sentences and simpler words. Replaced technical terms like 'RNA polymerase' and 'transcription factors' with 'RNA-making enzyme' and 'helper proteins'. Kept the correct answer and core idea the same.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: The core principle of biotechnology—harnessing biological systems and organisms to perform tasks or produce valuable substances.
Concept 2: Mechanisms/techniques—genetic engineering, tissue culture, and fermentation as methods that enable manipulation and production in biotechnology.
Concept 3: Relationships to applications and society—how biotechnology translates to medicine, agriculture, and environmental solutions, and how ethical considerations and regulation shape its use.

questions.question: Why must a functor satisfy $F(g \circ f) = F(g) \circ F(f)$?

options.A: It makes the image of a composed chain equal the composition of the images in the same order. The functor keeps how arrows compose.
options.B: It guarantees identity morphisms map to identity morphisms.
options.C: It makes objects map to objects that keep the same internal structure or labels.
options.D: It forces contravariant functors to flip the direction of arrows.

questions.simplification_notes: Made sentences shorter and clearer, used simple words, replaced ∘ with LaTeX $\circ$, kept the main idea and correct answer A.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Category structure (objects, morphisms, composition, identity) and how morphisms compose, generalizing function composition (e.g., a monoid as a single-object category).
Concept 2: Functors as structure-preserving mappings between categories (mapping objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms while preserving sources/targets; including contravariant functors).
Concept 3: Natural transformations as morphisms between functors, i.e., higher-level relationships between functors.

questions.question: How does extra CO2 from people make the ocean more acidic and change how carbon moves between the air, land, ocean, and rocks?

options.A: More CO2 in the air pushes extra CO2 into surface ocean water. There it reacts to form carbonic acid and lowers pH. Lower pH cuts carbonate ion levels and makes shell building harder. This changes how the ocean takes up and stores carbon and shifts carbon flows among the reservoirs.
options.B: Ocean life quickly turns the extra CO2 into solid carbonate shells and rocks, removing it from both air and water and keeping the cycle stable.
options.C: CO2 splits into carbon and oxygen high in the sky. Carbon falls into the deep ocean and oxygen escapes to space, so the cycle stays the same.
options.D: Rock weathering always fixes any extra CO2, so added atmospheric CO2 does not change ocean chemistry or carbon flows.

questions.simplification_notes: Used short sentences and simple words. Kept the main idea that human CO2 dissolves into seawater, forms carbonic acid, lowers pH, reduces carbonate ions, and alters how oceans store carbon. Made other options plausible but incorrect.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Fast carbon cycle vs. slow (deep/geological) carbon cycle: distinct timescales, reservoirs, and pathways that move carbon between atmosphere, biosphere, oceans, sediments, and Earth's interior.
Concept 2: Human perturbations alter natural carbon flows: land-use change and burning fossil fuels increase atmospheric CO2, driving climate change and ocean acidification.

Concept 3: Interlinked exchange processes and balance: carbon transfers are governed by chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes, with natural flows tending toward a balanced state absent human influence.

questions.question: How do open standards help very different systems truly work together? What makes this more than simple compatibility?

options.A: Open standards are public rules made by many groups. They define data formats and shared meanings so systems read and use exchanged information the same way, enabling end-to-end interoperability.
options.B: Open standards force one vendor's protocol on all products, making every product follow the same private rules.
options.C: Open standards only set syntax, not meaning. Systems can send data but might not interpret it in the same way.
options.D: Open standards are costly and exclusive, so few products adopt them and widespread working-together does not happen.

questions.simplification_notes: Split complex sentences, used simpler words, and kept the core idea that open standards give shared formats and meanings (semantic models) which enable true interoperability rather than just vendor-based compatibility.
concepts_tested: Concept 1: Syntactic vs semantic interoperability and the requirement of a common information exchange reference model for semantic interoperability.
Concept 2: The role of open standards in facilitating interoperability and the distinction between interoperability and mere compatibility.
Concept 3: Cross-domain interoperability as an extension that involves multiple social, organizational, political, and legal entities impacting information exchange.

questions.question: How do structured collaboration methods (like checking how you work, clear steps, and agreed rules) mainly help teams solve problems?

options.A: By forcing strict rules and a single leader so everyone follows one plan quickly.
options.B: By creating a shared picture and clear feedback so people spot problems, coordinate, and stay committed to the goal.
options.C: By having more meetings to gather opinions, which always brings faster agreement and better decisions.
options.D: By blaming individuals for failures so others change to avoid blame and try to gain more.
